title: Part a.
stimulusHtml:
2 points

  • 1 point No immediate change in the money supply

  • 1 point Currency falls but demand deposits increase (M= ↓C+ ↑D)
descriptions:
No points earned.

  • 1 point No immediate change in the money supply

  • 1 point Currency falls but demand deposits increase (M= ↓C+ ↑D)

Earns 1 of 2 points.

  • 1 point No immediate change in the money supply

  • 1 point Currency falls but demand deposits increase (M= ↓C+ ↑D)

Earns 2 of 2 points.

  • 1 point No immediate change in the money supply

  • 1 point Currency falls but demand deposits increase (M= ↓C+ ↑D)

title: Part b.
stimulusHtml:
2 points

  • 1 point $800

  • 1 point 1000 – 200 of required reserves = 800 (where 200 = 1000 x 0.20)
descriptions:
No points earned.

  • 1 point $800

  • 1 point 1000 – 200 of required reserves = 800 (where 200 = 1000 x 0.20)

Earns 1 of 2 points.

  • 1 point $800

  • 1 point 1000 – 200 of required reserves = 800 (where 200 = 1000 x 0.20)

Earns 2 of 2 points.

  • 1 point $800

  • 1 point 1000 – 200 of required reserves = 800 (where 200 = 1000 x 0.20)

title: Part c.
stimulusHtml:
2 points

  • 1 point $4,000

  • 1 point $4000 found by: $1000 x 5 and then subtract the $1000 that was already part of the money supply: $5000-1000 = $4000
    or $4000 found by multiplying $800 x 5
    (where 5 = Money multiplier = 1/ rr = 1/ 0.2)

  • Alternate explanation worth 1 point: $5000 found by $1000 x 5

title: Part d.
stimulusHtml:
1 point

Possible answers:

  • the public holding cash and not redepositing funds in banks

  • banks are unwilling to loan out all excess reserves (voluntary excess reserves)

  • the public is unwilling to demand loans (insufficient loan demand)

Not acceptable:

  • A change in reserve requirements (because this would change the maximum amount that can be lent out, but not the ability for the banking system to lend all that money)

Earns 1 of 1 point.

Possible answers:

  • the public holding cash and not redepositing funds in banks

  • banks are unwilling to loan out all excess reserves (voluntary excess reserves)

  • the public is unwilling to demand loans (insufficient loan demand)

Not acceptable:
